story:
It is with heavy heart that our family shares that, husband, father and grandfather, Yiannis Stylianou, passed away peacfully, at home surrounded by his wife and children on January 2nd 2021. He leaves behind his wife, Loukia, children, Steven, Andrew and Anthi, his grandchildren, Yiannis and Eirini.

He was the founder of the legendary Casablanca Jazz Club in Brighton. The longest running late night venue in Brighton The original live music venue. 

Yiannis was a well known and respected member of the Brighton and Greek Cypriot communities. A hardworking businessman, born into poverty, he devoted his life to helping his much-loved family and Greek community. 

A man of great strength and drive, he spoke of his proudest life’s achievements to be establishing his entire family, from a small agricultural village in Cyprus, into Brighton life and being a founding father of the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity, Brighton.

story: As many of you will know, towards the end of last year, my amazing Mum was diagnosed with breast cancer which required immediate Chemotherapy treatment in order to manage the spread of the cancer. Throughout the last few weeks, she has been nothing short of inspirational with her strength, positivity and thoughtfulness for others during what has been an extremely stressful and difficult time. One aspect that has been a challenge, has been coming to terms with the imminent loss of her infamous bleached blonde locks as a result of the Chemotherapy. This way we can enjoy lockdown together and laugh at our new appearances (and watch my hair grow back). This is in aid of Macmillan Cancer Research, the Number 1 cancer charity in the UK and therefore, if you could spare any money at all for a donation, it would be hugely appreciated and incredibly generous.

story: I was diagnosed in august 2019 with bowel cancer, i had to have a large amount of my bowel removed and a stoma fitted,in September 2019 i was told my cancer was terminal and with treatment i would possibly have 4-5 years left !!!!!as you can imagine we were deverstated. When my 1st lot of chemo was finished i had a scan they kept telling me there was alot of post op fluid but all was fine, after my 3rd scan they told me it wasnt fluid it was a tumour and the cancer was on my ovary too,they sent me to specialist in hampshire i went in on 19th june 2020 for my op on 22nd june, all went well, they removed a 6kg tumour, i had a full hysterectomy,appendix out, all the cancer cells scrapped away from stomach wall and a hot chemo wash out !!!!!  So not a small op, all went well till the sat 27th my oxygen levels kept dropping  and my kidneys were failing so i was rushed from the private clinic to baisingstoke and Hampshire hospital to hdu where i was put on to 100% oxygen and a kidney dialysis machine, i was,after 2/3 days transfered to icu i was put into an induced coma to help my body to recover, during this time my family had to make the decision to wake me from coma to pass away or to leave me in coma, they were going to leave me in the coma, the next thing i remember is waking up in icu on 20th july, not knowing what the hell has happened,i had a blue board bext to my bed with photos of the kids and a sign that said morning lisa you are in icu at Hampshire and baisingstoke hospital today is 20th july 2020........ i could barely talk as my vocal cords got damaged,i had a bad cough where i had been incubated so long ...... i had physio every day, i had nurses rolling me and patting my back trying to clear my chest,they were fantastic ..... when well enough i was sent up to a ward had my own room it was lovely, first week was rough as physio needed to start getting me up and i had no energy where i had lost so much muscle waste i ended up being away from my family for 11 weeks in that time i saw my daughter once, nick could only come once a week and i didnt see the boys in 2 months and my parents came twice a week, my brother woukd come when he could, all becsuse of covid and being so far away was very hard, my recovery is going well im getting there slowly, and i was cancer free for a while but it is now on my liver, ive just had 6 rounds of chemo and waiting on next scan, my hair is thinned and all different lengths so ive decided to shave it and raise money while im at it for macmillan as they are fantastic and have helped us to no end, PLEASE HELP ME RAISE AS MUCH AS WE CAN XXXXX

Our first charity is Macmillan Cancer Support. We know a lot of friends and family who've relied on the support of this charity, so it means a lot to us! In two months we plan on raising money for another charity, Wateraid. Then we'll decide on another charity and will keep going throughout this lockdown.

Please donate whatever you can and feel free to join in at home too!

Thanks for supporting our fundraising.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Sadly my Nan lost her fight to Heart Disease on the 29th Dec 20.  She was the kindest person you would have ever liked to meet.  She had a great life and was a major part of my families life.  Reaching the grand age of 84 up until a couple of years ago she was fighting fit, given a new lease of life after recieving a new Heart Valve in her 70's she was the life and sole of the family circle.

Sadly the Heart Failure started to take hold in 2019 and she spent most of the year in and out of York, Selby Hospitals, which had its up and downs.  The worst of this was Dec 2019  when she suffered a suspected Heart attack in hospital, it was heart breaking to see my Nan reduced to not been strong enough to eat or talk in York, spending a long time by her side at York thinking the worst.  

But in true Supernan fashion she battled through and managed to pull through, with the work of the team at York her medication was balanced out and she got some independence back and my Mum and Dad made the decsion to down size to a Bungalow and move my Nan in with them and my Mum act as her carer.  She was determined to keep going and managed to get mobile again using a frame she built upon the strength and confidence to have a daily walk round the estate to keep active

Then Covid came in 2020 but in the true War Generation fashion she cracked on and kept active.  

Sadly in Dec 20 signs that she was deteriating was starting to show, putting on a brave face and determined not to miss Christmas she ploughed on, but was clearly very unwell,  struggling to move and out of breath moving short distences, tell tail signs the medication for her heart was struggling.  We were all hoping it would be able to be made more comfortable by rebalancing the medication via specialist advice from the heart ward in York. But unfortunately the disease had come to its natural end and my Nan sadly passed away in her sleep peacefully on the 29th Dec 20.  The only saving grace is she is out of pain and now at peace.

The point of this page is to try and raise some funds towards future research for Heart Disease but the British Heart Foundation. All funds will go direct to the British Heart Foundation.

This has been created in preparation for my Nan's Funeral on the 20th Jan 2021 at Selby Abbey, before been laid to rest with her soul mate my Grandad.

story:
My sister Rebecca and I have joined forces this year to complete this challenge together. 

This is now my 3rd year- please help support us by donating and or sharing our page please. 

We are doing this first in memory of our beloved Dad who was only 57 when he passed away suddenly of a heart attack on 8th September 2016, his birthday is the 1st March which is the day the dechox starts so is a lovely way to honour his memory. 

Our Grandad (Dads dad) also passed away aged 49 of heart problems 40 years ago. 

Also Gemma has another reason not forgetting my beautiful goddaughter Winter was taken to be an angel at just 5 weeks old also due to heart problems. 

                          *****************

For anyone that knows us they will know how much we love chocolate and most of all cake! But this year we are giving up chocolate, cake, sweets and fizzy drinks for 31 days! 

So far you have helped Gemma raise £424.38 so I thank you so much for your support. But this year working as a team we hope to smash it! 

Please donate anything you can as every little helps and kindly share the page for me

story:
The British Heart Foundation is a fantastic charity. A lot of people associate it with heart attacks, when In fact, they support people who have suffered strokes, heart disease, high blood pressure and more. All are very dangerous health conditions. 

Chocolates, sweets & fizzy drinks do not help conditions such as these,  they have a lot of sugar and fat In them, and these can cause a lot of damage. which is why I’ve chosen to take on this challenge and give awareness.

Everyone that knows me, will know that I live for my hot chocolates & squirty cream and half a pack of biscuits with every cup of tea, so this will be quite the challenge, but if it means adding more money to the pot then BRING IT ON. 

I am relying on your donations to give me all the encouragement I need to get through it 💪🏻 And hey, you never know, I could even lose a bit of weight with this lol 

(Mason won’t be joining me for this particular fundraiser, i wouldn’t be so cruel lol) 

I’ll share updates on my Facebook/Instagram stories to keep you all up to date with how I’m doing - wish me luck 🤞🏻

I am going to treat myself to the BIGGEST Easter egg I can find after this lol

story:
Almost two million people in the UK are living with sight loss that has a significant impact on their daily lives. Of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone and lead lonely, isolated lives. 

Guide Dogs works for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life, for a world where being blind or partially sighted is not what defines you. A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling hopes and dreams.

story:
How can I make a (small) difference during this COVID pandemic?

I like to run, relatively short distances...and I was struck by a report in December, from Cancer Research, that announced cuts of £45 million to its research budget, due to the pandemic from cancellation of fundraising events and closure of their shops.

Their research is so important to so many, so I have decided to set myself a challenge.

I have committed to run a total of 240km, starting on 11 January 2021. If I run a minimum of 2Okm per week, it'll take me 12 weeks...so that's the goal! 

The distance is the equivalent of virtually running around the London Outer Orbital Path – known as the “London Loop”.

Thank you for your support. It means a lot.

Love,  Amelia B x

story:
The Marie Curie Bradford Hospice supports people living with a terminal illness and those closest to them to live as well as possible.  

The Hospice is often very different from what people expect  it is a warm, friendly space with beautiful gardens, delicious home-cooked food and personalised care. Every person is treated as an individual and helped to reach their goals and fulfil their wishes. A team of nurses, doctors, social workers, physiotherapists, chaplains, bereavement counsellors and pharmacists work together, putting every person at the centre of their care.  

Throughout Covid-19 Bradford Hospice teams have been working around the clock to continue supporting local people. Death, dying and bereavement is at the forefront of peoples minds and Marie Curie knows what a difference the right care at the end of life can make.

story:
Sally unexpectedly passed away on Tuesday 5th January. She will be dearly missed by all those that worked with her and had the pleasure of meeting her.

In true Sally style we have composed the poem below and can only hope that she would have approved!


An Ode to Sally

The Angels were complaining about the lack of help they had

Heaven was so busy; God knew that it was bad

God could see that it was tricky at his hotel in the sky

But help is had to come by, when your standards are so high


This job was more than friendly, greeting people role

He needed someone organised – that just loved to take
control

Someone strong of character, to get him out this hole

It’s a tough ask to find a person, that can deal with every
soul

A pinch of caring, dash of daring, nip of dirty laugh

Someone to find AMAZING out of something that is naff


God looked at all his Angels looking very glum

He sighed and knew he needed to have someone bring in fun

He put Pinot in the cooler and Poldark on repeat

He had to make his offer so fabulously neat

He put food of every flavour to tempt a person’s soul

And thought “I’ll even serve crisps, crushed up and in a
bowl”


Angels don’t you worry, the solution to our phones

I called her and she accepted, the amazing Sally Jones

story:
This year I will be running the London Landmarks Half Marathon to support the WWF, their initiatives are at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources.

Especially during the global pandemic, the huge hit taken by the tourism sector has drastically reduced the funds that help these projects stay alive. Just this summer I have visited myself the Orebetello's natural oasis, a land the WWF acquired in 1977 with the goal of protecting its unique natural habitat. I would love to be able to show such places to my sons and nephews some day and hope they will still hold the beauty they currently display; take a look at the photos above.

As a member of the WWF since my childhood, when I used to take part to summer camps at their natural reserves in Italy, I recognize how important it is for us to make an effort to help these places survive, to help sustain their wildlife and their flora for future generations to come.

*********************************************************************

Quest'anno correro' la London Landmark mezza maratona per sostenere il WWF; le loro iniziative sono al centro degli sforzi globali per affrontare le sfide ambientali piu' importanti del nostro pianeta: salvaguardare il mondo naturale, affrontare cambiamenti climatici e consentire a tutti noi di accedere alla giusta quantita' di risorse naturali.

Soprattutto durante la pandemia, le perdite subite dal settore del turismo hanno ridotto in modo significante i fondi che supportanto questi progetti. Proprio quest'estate ho visitato l'oasi naturale di Orbetello, il WFF acquisto' il terreno nel 1977 con l'obiettivo di tutelarne il suo unico habitat naturale. Spero di poter mostrare questi luoghi ai miei figli e nipoti con la speranza che conservino la bellezza che mostrano oggi; date un occhio alle foto sopra.

Come membro del WWF da bambino, riconosco quanto sia importante per tutti noi fare uno sforzo per aiutare questi luoghi a rimanere intatti, permettendo alla fauna e flora locale di sopravvivere per generazioni a venire.

story:
For me personally the reason I’ve chosen to take part in ‘The Big Winter Wander’ to raise money for WWF-UK is not just because of the respite nature has given us collectively in the last year as COVID became part of our lives, it’s not just because our wildlife is under threat from the destruction our human behaviours can have on animals and their habitats (although this is such a super serious issue) ... it’s also because of everything nature has personally given me and it’s time to do something to pay that back in anyway I can. 

For those of you that don’t know I became really ill three years ago, I was diagnosed with Functional Neurological Disorder which had a massive impact on my life. I went from living a busy and active lifestyle to being housebound, unable to walk, and unable to care for myself. Nature became my everyday escape, something I had always loved was still there and still accessible in some ways to me. I might not have been able to go outside for such a long time but I could bird watch from my windows, I could listen to the wildlife and feel the fresh air with my window open, I could watch the seasons change and the life in my little garden adapt through each season. Three years later I have learnt to walk again, I’m strong enough to do it (often with the aid of my stick) and regularly potter off to enjoy my local park just in the company of my dog on a good day.

It took time but through this battle nature has been such a blessing for me. It became part of my goals; first getting out into the garden in my wheelchair to sit and enjoy the fresh air, next it was taking a few steps into the garden with a walking aid as I became stronger and learnt to take one step after another, then having the confidence to take a mobility scooter and, under supervision, ride it up to the park and eventually start to take tentative steps on paths with a slight incline, next it was building up stamina and learning to climb up and down steps. Anytime I needed to have a break I could just stop and watch nature change and grow around me as my life did the same. 

Throughout the last three lockdowns and all of 2020, surrounded by nature and the support of loved ones, I’ve gone from strength to strength and have made some massive steps forward (pun intended). COVID may have put a restriction on the intended date for ‘The Big Winter Wander’ and what exactly can be done but here’s the plan; 

. Initially WWF-UK had planned for the event to take place on Sunday the 24th of January but, following lockdown 3.0 they have decided to reschedule the event with a date TBC. However, per their update and email, if people can safely still take part they are welcome to at anytime and in various ways with all fundraising still going towards the cause. In order to stick to lockdown legislation and Government guidelines I have decided to do my walk over the period of a week starting on Monday the 18th of January and ending on Sunday the 24th of January. This will be my legally allowed and COVID safe one outdoor exercise activity per day. 

. This will be a huge challenge for me covering four miles a day for seven consecutive days totalling 28 miles over the week. Baring in mind this time last year I was still regularly using my wheelchair I do have to ensure my safety so some days I will be joined (socially distanced) by a member of my support bubble, each day I will have my dog with me as company, and for every walk I will also be using my walking stick for support. 

. I will be walking the same route each day around Wollaton Park in Nottingham which is a three minute walk from my house and is therefore within my local area and adheres to COVID regulations. 

. Although I have the sheets for fundraising because of being unable to meet people outside of my bubble I have to rely on online donations so, if you do very nicely choose to sponsor me, please do so via my Just Giving page www.justgiving/francescarachel

story:
Hello gals and guys,

My lovely friend Anita Nixon and I are putting on our hiking boots and participating in the Jurassic Coast Challenge; walking 100km over 2 days from Poole to West Bay all in the name of charity. 

2020 was a bit of a disaster, and while we are all hoping for better in 2021, parting with your hard earned cash during a pandemic is tough. However, 2020 was also a disaster for our natural world. Wildfires, floods, earthquakes. And this is just the tip of the (thawing) iceberg. But, WWF are doing pretty amazing things for Mother Earth, addressing the most important environmental challenges and safeguarding the natural world to ensure a sustainable future for us all. Clean oceans. Stable climates. Thriving rainforests. Sustainable economies. Wildlife! All the wildlife. If you care about these things, please donate to allow WWF to continue their amazing work championing nature and vulnerable communities all over the world. If you don’t, then you really should, so donate anyway!

Just think of all that money you’re saving during lockdown; from the pubs and restaurants being shut, not having to drive to work due to WFM, or not grabbing a takeaway coffee on the commute (which in itself is good for the environment, so double whammy!)

If you like me and there’s a good chance you’d buy me a beer if you saw me in the pub, then a cheeky £5 donation is a simple way to make up for not having the pleasure of doing so. If you don’t like me but are rather partial to our wonderful planet Earth, donate anyway, but do it anonymously and it can be your little secret. 

In all seriousness, any donation big or small will be massively appreciated. If you can’t donate right now, I totally understand. Things are hard right now. You may have lost your job, or are struggling with your business, or be on furlough, making your finances tighter. So a little ‘like’ of support will also be appreciated and I will remember it with each painful step towards the finish line. All donations will be met with a virtual fist bump and a promise to express my gratitude in person when we are allowed to mingle carefree once again 

Thank you wonderful people for reading and I wish every single one of you all the best for 2021. Stay safe 💜

story:
John Winder sadly passed away on 30th December 2020 at home after a short illness, with family at his side. Much loved by Cherry his wife of 61 years, and offspring Mark (& Lena), Paul (& Muna), Rachel (& Robin) and Jane (& Stuart), and 5 grandchildren, Johanna, Jasper, Amelia, Finlay and Freya.

In these difficult times, John will be laid to rest soon in a private and, unfortunately, very restricted ceremony. Please donate to Dad's charities instead of sending flowers (as a water engineer, Dad was passionate about improving people's lives through provision of clean water in many parts of the world). 

You are also invited to share your thoughts and memories of John when you donate, if you wish. Should you prefer an alternative charity to Water Aid, Dad was also a keen supporter of Amnesty International and UNICEF UK.

Thank you,   Cherry, Mark, Paul, Rachel, Jane
